Topic.Title: is the writer of this article credible?

Message.Msg: It's also good to keep a sense of perspective, iPhone is on its 5th generation and iPad and Galaxy on their 3rd generations yet Intel still made $5bn operating cash last quarter which is close to historical highs. Intel could suspend buybacks for a quarter and instantly find another billion net profit, that's how much slack there is in the profit margins. 2013Q3-Q4 is when the Windows 8/Haswell/Clovertrail factors start showing up in the bottom line, everybody has one more year to accumulate at these very low stock prices because they won't be seen again after 2013.

Message.Title: Just A Thought
Message.Msg: After bumping into resistance defined by the top of the short term down channel started in mid-September, the major indexes again failed to break out yesterday/thursday. This suggests that the path of least resistance is to pull back to the bottom of that down channel. With that said, things can change quickly during earnings season. AAPL has yet to report. For those which have reported, we'll have to see whether the stocks that received positive price reactions (financials) can keep the momentum going, and for those that were hit (techs), where they can find stabilization. have a nice day

Topic.Title: Is Intel chips in any tablets??

Message.Msg: None that sell any. Tablets are going for $99 - $200 these days. Nobody will put a $100 or even a $50 chip in tablets. The tablet space belongs to $25 ARM chips and Intel simply cannot compete there. the days of PCs with a $300 processor are gone and are not coming back. The sooner people on this board realize that, the better.

Message.Title: If gross margins drop to 50%, Intel profits will be ZERO
Message.Msg: Intel can go to 14nm, 5nm or 0nm. None of that will change the fact that NOBODY is willing to pay $300 for a processor that costs Intel $50 to produce. The future is with $25 - $50 ARM processors. Intel's monopoly pricing power is a thing of the past and margins are going down no matter what the company does. Q4 margins are expected to be 57%. At 50% GMs Intel will have ZERO profits. What is going to happen to your precious dividend then?

Topic.Title: If gross margins drop to 50%, Intel profits will be ZERO

Message.Msg: yeah just like the future was with cheap low power Transmeta, Via, Amd chips ... oh wait all those cheapo companies are either dead or dying and Intel could still charge hundreds of dollars for their top skus while they were dying lol. People will always pay top dollar for their PC processors as battery life is irrelevant in that category and Intel Ivy Bridges/Haswell beat ARM A15s more badly than they beat up Bulldozer lol. Those who forget the lessons of history will be doomed to repeat the mistakes of history ;-).

Topic.Title: If gross margins drop to 50%, Intel profits will be ZERO

Message.Msg: 14% of PC owners have moved to tablets and say they will NOT but a new PC. Get with the times. The age of the PC is coming to an end.

Topic.Title: If gross margins drop to 50%, Intel profits will be ZERO

Message.Msg: Transmeta, AMD and Via were a second generation of chip vendors trying to compete with the pioneer Intel. In mobile, the pioneer is ARM so its a different ballgame where Intel is trying to catch up. Also, look how small ARM is and look how unaffected its fortunes are with the ups and downs in the chip industry. It's unique business model gives it staying power. It can compete in a long drawn out battle with Intel over microprocessors. None of the companies you mentioned had this advantage.

Topic.Title: If gross margins drop to 50%, Intel profits will be ZERO

Message.Msg: 14% wow, I bet Otellini is shaking in his option filled boots lol ! I bet that was not 14% of enterprises only 14% of consumer (cheapskates) who Intel have never relied on for the bulk of their profits.

Topic.Title: If gross margins drop to 50%, Intel profits will be ZERO

Message.Msg: ARM has no money it less able to compete than those other companies were. Intel has already caught up with ARM in mobile and that is only with its 32nm generation and the 22nm generation is 1 year away and the 14nm generation only a year after that. Meanwhile ARM has no processor that can remotely compete with Ivy Bridge/Haswell/Broadwell so over the next few years Intel is going to be dishing out punishment to ARM with no real response. ARM has had it easy up to now in Mobile but now it's got real competition and it is already making it look bad.

Topic.Title: If gross margins drop to 50%, Intel profits will be ZERO

Message.Msg: My point is ARM doesn't need money to compete with Intel. It is leveraged against Intel indirectly through its licensees. Some would say that the days of people clamoring for greater compute power because Intel was pitching that through its marketing machine are over. The next generation microprocessor performs reasonably well but has great battery life. Look at Apple's A6. They only clocked it at 1.3GHz. ARM doesn't really have competition from Intel in mobile because unlike Intel's view of the real market picture, the competition for mobile is not on performance as Intel would have us believe but better battery life and better integration of features such as radios and graphics subsystems. Intel has never played this game before. Its used to dictating terms and that shows in its approach to this market too.

Topic.Title: If gross margins drop to 50%, Intel profits will be ZERO

Message.Msg: 'Some would say that the days of people clamoring for greater compute power because Intel was pitching that through its marketing machine are over.' Customers have always decided with their own money what level of computing power they want and what price they will pay for it, marketing had very little to do with it. 'ARM doesn't really have competition from Intel in mobile because unlike Intel's view of the real market picture, the competition for mobile is not on performance as Intel would have us believe but better battery life and better integration of features such as radios and graphics subsystems. Intel has never played this game before. Its used to dictating terms and that shows in its approach to this market too.' Medifeld beats the latest Snapdragon on both javascript performance and overall application battery life in the exact same phone. The next phone chip still at 32nm, CloverTrail+ will have dual-core with 4 total threads, LTE, and a 533 MHz SGX543MP2 which will match any other phone chip in graphics performance. Your POV is so out of date.

Topic.Title: If gross margins drop to 50%, Intel profits will be ZERO

Message.Msg: To push its mobile offerings in the future, Intel will have to compete with Apple on the basis of generically produced reference platforms. Its best case scenario is Motorola which is backed by Google of Android fame not Samsung which is still behind Apple in terms of market image. Its improvements in performance are not going to be enough to compete with the industry leading design powerhouse on the overall customer experience. The current dynamic suggests it will become a fringe player with say 10% of the mobile chip market optimistically speaking. Not very lucrative considering how much competition it will face from established players for that 10%. To give this number a reference, current market share is 0.2%.

Topic.Title: NYK2OH gets his tail kicked by Marsavian, part 1

Message.Msg: One thing to add to Marsavian's comment is - the $300 GPU market is considerably smaller, Intel needs to sell several times the size of the GPU market. But I think they will - by extending the SKU's up and down. Intel will target a CPU/SoC against each competitive CPU/SoC and offer price/performance advantages to OEMs (Intel has repeatedly and successfully done this against AMD). Intel's competitors will have to compete intensely with its lower-end SKUs. I recall Microsoft got into trouble by talking about cutting-off the air supply for Netscape by making the browser available free for commercial use. Intel will seek to do the same to its competition by keeping margins to a minimum for the lower-end SKUs and let its competition bleed - while delivering higher-end SKUs for good, decent margins. (Lower margins/prices benefit consumers, so to my knowledge, a manufacturer keeping margins/prices low are not a basis for anti-trust laws to kick in.) The icing on the cake might be Intel keeping its usual margins on lower-end SKUs due to its process/node advantages while bleeding the competition dry. While Intel will sell a lot of lower-end SKUs, it will also sell higher-end SKUs for good, decent margins. Intel has repeatedly pointed out how their own Celerons and Pentiums (lower-end) don't find favor with a lot of buyers who want to move up the chain to a higher-end CPU since it is a item purchases for 2-4 years of use. So I expect Intel to continue selling huge volumes of higher-end SKUs as well. We'll see how this all plays out.

Topic.Title: NYK2OH gets his tail kicked by Marsavian, part 1

Message.Msg: A fantasy world is what you inhabit if your think Intel's asp is $300. Do you think if you repeat a lie enough times it suddenly becomes true ? There are analysts who do detailed Intel sku price/volume breakdowns like Mercury and they are usually found repeated on sites like Investorvillage. Why don't you go look one up before opening your mouth and proving you're a fool rather than just letting us suspect it. Also Intel has never truly been a monopoly in the x86 industry, when AMD brought out Athlon and Athlon 64 it caused a major shock to Intel prices, profits and marketshare. It recovered by outdesigning and outfabricating AMD which is exactly what it will do to all the ARM pretenders who covet its profits. AMD has been in Intel's palm ever since Core 2 Duo and it has skus as cheap as ARM now but which are still better performing yet still they have no effect on Intel's pricing. If AMD couldn't do it then ARM has no chance with relatively anemic designs like A15 and S4 which can't even beat Atom.

The predominant share of Intel's business is going to be 22nm very quickly because the Intel ramp is so superior to that of TSMC and the ARM world. Topic.Title: If gross margins drop to 50%, Intel profits will be ZERO

Message.Msg: Everybody focusing on INTC's margins - what about TSMC's margins? - NO reason for Intel not able to match TSMC's margins - Intel probably exceeds. And here is where WS goes stupid is Intel the ONLY one that has to deliver super high margins in mobile? TSMC makes a good portion on DEPRECIATED production lines - Intel can use "traditional" CPU business to cover depreciation - those ARM fan boys should take agood look at TSMC 2013 capex projections - ARM has far more challenge to maintain its margin structure because in the past they were spoiled - just 12 months ago process technology / manufacturing was no issu for ARM. No suddenly TSMC chasing FinFets and EUV. TI exiting mobile - how come nobody asked WHY - because TI realized they can make better returns in Analog rather sitting in the ARM SoC frying pan. QCOM and NVDA have to choice (to fall back on alternative business- sink or swim. It's well documented that QCOM CEO is VERY concerned about fabless economics going forward From: Will Finfets Affect ARM? Next year is slated for the introduction of Atom-based handset SOCs from Intel out on its 22nm finfet process, will that make Intel's wireless chip-sets competitive? No, says ARM's CEO Warren East. "We expect the 22nm process will give them some advantage in power consumption, but whether that advantage is sufficient to make them competitive remains to be seen," Warren East told me a couple of weeks ago, "they're saying the process will give them 20% more power efficiency but they're a lot more than 20% less efficient than ARM." Asked the same question, Mike Bryant replies: "Unlike in small systems where it is key, in big systems, which smartphones most definitely are nowadays, the instruction set used is far less relevant with only 10% to 15% of power dealing with it. So even if ARM waved magic dust on their instruction set, which isn't perfect anyway, they can only optimise 10% to 15% of the power used. More power goes in moving data around the chip, and most goes to moving data on and off the chip to memory and peripherals." "ARM programs can actually use a few percent more codespace than Intel but let's say they are the same," adds Bryant, "next of course the data either processor has to be moved around - be it pictures, voice data, HTML or just the call set-up protocol, is identical for each processor. Finally the video data has to be transferred onto the display and for all the hype ARM's Mali is about the same as GPUs from Intel or Nvidia, though there are slightly more efficient solutions from Imagination Technologies or Qualcomm's Adreno." "So for a pure ARM system against a pure Intel system, 85% of the power usage is independent of the processor instruction set and dependent purely on the process technology," concludes Bryant.

Topic.Title: NYK2OH gets his tail kicked by Marsavian, part 1

Message.Msg: In those geekbench benchmarks you quoted dual-core Atom has the better integer performance by factors of 1.44,1.19,1.82 over its dual-core A6, quad-core A9, dual-core S4 rivals. Now the nearest Atom SoC rival to these ARM chips is the 1.7W 1.8GHz Clovertrail arkDOTintelDOTcom/products/70105/Intel-Atom-Processor-Z2760-1MB-Cache-1_80-GHz Even assuming perfect descaling of performance with clockspeed decrease (unlikely) i.e. 1.80/2.13 = 84% you would still get 1.21, 1, 1.54 advantage factors for Atom so it still does not get beaten. Now this Clovertrail part has an on die memory controller which means the ~20ns latency associated with desktop Atom's FSB is removed so that will more than make up for the 16% clock decrease in many cases. So it is true what I said, Atom is not beaten by current ARM chips on integer performance (which is the most important for commercial applications) and definitely won't be per core by any planned ARM chip for the foreseeable future.

Message.Title: Intel’s Haswell is an unprecedented threat to Nvidia, AMD
Message.Msg: "Market" seems to be brain dead - maybe Intel needs to do better job in "educating" the anals - but on the other hand a lot of sell side anals are not interested - this board also show how little understanding the Intel basher have Intel is building Haswell inventory - don't they seems to be a double whammy for NVDA and AMD - Bernstein crock pumped up AMD a week ago Haswell’s GPU turns the screws on Nvidia, AMD Haswell’s GPU is a tweaked version of the cores currently deployed in Ivy Bridge. What’s really changing is the shader loadout; Intel will offer Haswell in 10, 20, and 40-shader flavors (GT1, GT2, and GT3). The chip will also be offered in variants that include up to 128MB in on-package RAM, a feature that provides the GPU with a small dedicated pool of memory. Intel isn’t talking much about the GPU changes, but the company has stated that the new GT3 configuration offers “up to 2x” the performance of Ivy Bridge’s HD 4000 graphics. Even a conservative take on that promise spells trouble for AMD and Nvidia. According to figures from Anandtech, Trinity’s GPU is an average of 18% faster than Llano’s across a range of 15 popular titles. Compared to Sandy Bridge, Trinity was almost 80% faster. Against Ivy Bridge, it’s just 20% faster. Given what we know of Haswell’s GPU shader counts and performance targets, it shouldn’t be hard for Intel to deliver a 30-50% performance boost in real-world games. If it does, Trinity goes from the fastest integrated GPU on the market to an also-ran, and AMD loses the superior graphics hole card it’s been playing since it launched the AMD 780G chipset four years ago.

Topic.Title: NYK2OH gets his tail kicked by Marsavian, part 1

Message.Msg: Even assuming perfect descaling of performance with clockspeed decrease (unlikely) i.e. 1.80/2.13 = 84% you would still get 1.21, 1, 1.54 advantage factors for Atom so it still does not get beaten. Now this Clovertrail part has an on die memory controller which means the ~20ns latency associated with desktop Atom's FSB is removed so that will more than make up for the 16% clock decrease in many cases. So it is true what I said, Atom is not beaten by current ARM chips on integer performance (which is the most important for commercial applications) and definitely won't be per core by any planned ARM chip for the foreseeable future. ----- :) We will see what Clovertrail can do in reality. I think you would be surprised at how much float is used these days, especially in GUI frameworks etc. Anyways, your originally comment was: "ARM has no chance with relatively anemic designs like A15 and S4 which can't even beat Atom." The reality is even the A9 can beat Atom in floating point. As for the A15, we shall soon see...

Topic.Title: Intel’s Haswell is an unprecedented threat to Nvidia, AMD

Message.Msg: lol The likely release timeframe for Haswell is close to June 2013, there's still tons of time between now and then. Haswell builds on the same fundamental GPU architecture we saw in Ivy Bridge. We won't see a dramatic redesign/re-plumbing of the graphics hardware until Broadwell in 2014 (that one is going to be a big one). AMD/NVIDIA are not sleeping either, what next?

Topic.Title: Intel’s Haswell is an unprecedented threat to Nvidia, AMD

Message.Msg: Intel has to spend hundreds of millions just to acheive the next evolution of their own graphics chips and they are still several generations behind AMD and nVidia. They are so far behind in a race that they will probably never catch up. AMD and Nvidia are setting the standards for graphic core HPC and Intel has no choice but to follow suit. Intel is in a position that they do not like. They have ARMH chipping away at the bottom end and AMD an Nvidia both leading the way in grapics. We are soon coming to the place where there will be NO meaningful reason that PI should be calculated to bazillion decimal points 5 seconds faster for a $300.00 difference in cpu price. If you can not perceive a difference then there is no difference. ARMH $30 SoC vs Intel $300 processors? Fundamental shift puts Intel Upside down on Revenue and Margins next and even 14nm can not save them

Topic.Title: Intel’s Haswell is an unprecedented threat to Nvidia, AMD

Message.Msg: Much more important than the gpu improvements is the fact that from Ivy Bridge to Haswell the integer execution units increase from 3 to 4, the load units increase from 3 to 4 and the execution ports increase from 6 to 8. The cache bandwidth also DOUBLES. Haswell will now be able to simultaneously decode, load and execute 4 integer instructions per cycle. The theoretical improvement in integer applications that are wide enough to take care of it is 33% and maybe even more due to other improvements like the cache bandwidth and other widenings of the OoO core. The floating point power also DOUBLES. Intel is sandbagging to keep Ivy Bridge sales up, Haswell is just going to be a performance monster, the most perfectly balanced symmetrical powerful x86 processor ever designed. The specs just don't lie.

Message.Title: Deep Inside Intel with Mark Bohr, senior fellow at Intel
Message.Msg: semimdDOTcom/blog/2012/10/18/deep-inside-intel/ By Ed Sperling Semiconductor Manufacturing & Design sat down with Mark Bohr, senior fellow at Intel, to talk about a wide range of manufacturing and design issues Intel is wrestling with at advanced nodes—and just how far the road map now extends. SMD: Will EUV make 10nm? And if it doesn’t, what effect will that have on Intel? Bohr: For a process module as critical as lithography, Intel always has more than one option we pursue. In this era, the options are either EUV or 193nm immersion with multi-patterning. SMD: How about directed self-assembly? Bohr: That’s not a universally usable approach. You still need to define some layers with direct patterning, not a self-assembly technique. That’s a niche direction that will not replace these mainstream lithography techniques, but there may be some layers where it can complement the normal patterning techniques. SMD: What’s your opinion about the future of the foundry business? Bohr: The traditional foundry model is running into problems. In order to survive, the foundries will have to become more like an integrated device manufacturer. Even some of the chief spokespeople for the foundries have said something similar. The foundry model worked well when traditional scaling was being followed and everybody knew where we were headed. In this era, where you continually have to invent new materials and new structures, it’s a lot tougher being a separate foundry and maskless design house. Being an IDM, we have design and process development under one roof. That’s really a significant advantage. SMD: Can even Intel afford to be an independent IDM? The cost of building state-of-the-art fabs at future nodes is astronomical. Bohr: Yes. We have the volume and the products that can fill multiple fabs. SMD: But you’ve also opened up your fabs to at least a couple customers. Are you planning on extending that? , Bohr: Our motivation is that we know we have great process technology, and partnering with other strategic companies can be a win-win situation. We can sell our technology and make more money off what we’ve developed, and they can have some very compelling products. It’s not Intel’s goal to be a general-purpose foundry, but we will be partnering where it makes strategic sense. SMD: Is Intel sticking to bulk CMOS or will move to new materials such as fully depleted SOI? Bohr: We see more advantages in bulk than SOI. I won’t say SOI won’t be in the future. There may be some device structure that is better done in SOI than bulk. But I don’t see than happening right now. When we first announced that we were making TriGate or finFET devices at 22nm, we said we’re making these devices on SOI, as well. But we think there are cost advantages to doing TriGate on bulk rather than SOI. That’s our plan for the foreseeable future. SMD: What comes after the current finFET? Bohr: The finFET is scalable to 14nm. SMD: But if you’re at 22nm, 14nm isn’t very far away, so you’ve got to be working on the next step. Bohr: For Intel, you’re right. For other companies, it’s many years away. For 10nm, which is where I’m spending most of my time these days, I know we have a solution. I can’t elaborate at this point. SMD: At 10nm aren’t you running into quantum effects? Bohr: Everything gets different and tougher, but the problems are solvable—at least at that generation. SMD: How far ahead can you see? Bohr: I know we can get to 10nm. Beyond that, our research group is working on solutions for 7nm and 5nm. I have confidence we’ll have solutions for those. But by the time we’re down to 5nm we’ll be looking at non-familiar devices and device structures. That’s what we’ll have to do to get down to that level. SMD: Where do stacked die fit into your roadmap? Bohr: 3D stacked die have advantages, but only for certain market segments. You have to be very clear about what problem and what market segment you’re trying to serve. For a small handheld application where a small footprint and form factor are key and power levels are low, it probably makes good sense to use 3D stacking. For desktop, laptop and server applications where form factor isn’t as valuable and power levels are higher, 3D stacking has some problems that make it not an ideal solution. SMD: Along those lines, does Intel see the smart phone and small mobile device market as a key direction? Bohr: Intel is very serious about getting into the smart phone and tablet markets. We are a very different company from what we were five or six years ago. We are developing process technologies, but also products, that span a much wider range of performance and power than anywhere in our history. We’re not just after the high-performance desktop. We’re developing products that support 100-watt server chips down to sub-1 watt smart phone chips. SMD: There are a number of interesting techniques Intel is working with, such as near-threshold computing. How will power management start changing inside these chips? Bohr: When you’re talking about developing a smart phone chip that is ultra low power that also provides improved performance features that the market expects, you have to pull every trick out of the bag. You need great transistor technology, great package technology, great CPU architectures, the ability to turn off parts of the chip when you don’t need them so you’re saving power, the software links with the chip design so the software knows when to throttle power down. You need transistors, CPU architecture and software to be effective in that space. SMD: How many cores will be required in the future? Bohr: It depends on the market. In the server market, the more cores you can pack on the better. But in desktops, laptops and smart phones, there’s probably a limit to how many cores are practical. It’s not one. It’s probably several. SMD: But less than eight? Bohr: Yes, probably less than eight. But when you talk about the number of cores and computing engines, it depends on whether you’re dealing with traditional computing tasks where four cores are better than two cores. If you’re talking about execution engines in a graphics processor, clearly you want more cores. SMD: What does this do for Intel’s platform strategy, particularly as you go after many markets with very specific needs? Bohr: Even for Intel there are probably an optimal number of chip designs. It’s not like in the past where we tried to make one size fit all or have one chip serve multiple markets. But on the other hand, trying to design and manufacture dozens of very different designs in a generation is also impractical. There’s an optimal number of designs, although I don’t know what that number is, that can best meet the market requirements. You want to make as few iterations between the different designs as you can or re-use the cores or some of the circuit blocks between the different chips so you’re not completely redesigning it. SMD: Are there other materials being considered for transistors? Bohr: Our research group has been publishing papers about using 3-5 materials http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_semiconductor_materials for the channels. You deposit indium phosphide or gallium arsenide layer on top of silicon to make a transistor on the surface. It’s still a silicon wafer, but you’re looking at depositing more exotic materials. That’s new and different and it may happen, but it’s not yet fully resolved how good that approach may be. SMD: Has the priority for what you’re designing into a chip changed? Is it still all about performance, or has power overtaken that? Bohr: Ten or 15 years ago, performance was the main goal in developing a new process technology. That really has gone away as the No. 1 priority. We still strive to provide a performance boost with each new technology, but there’s much more emphasis on improving power or efficiency on each new generation. We do that by reducing active power for the work a chip does. That’s a much more important goal for us today. Part of the reason is that the market has shifted from desktop applications to more mobile products. The first transition was from desktops to laptops. Now the move is to put things into smart phones. Today’s consumer wants computing power he can hold in his hand in the form factor of a smart phone and a tiny battery. He wants the performance he had on his laptop only three or four years ago. That’s what we shoot for. SMD: That shifts the biggest challenge to the architecture, right? Bohr: Yes. Whether it’s low-power, low-leakage transistors or a more efficient core architecture—or linking that with more efficient software. SMD: What becomes the next big bottleneck? Bohr: We have lots of challenges. Lithography is the key challenge in making transistors smaller. Whether EUV will happen on time or we have to extend immersion using multiple patterning. But when you make transistors smaller they don’t become less leaky. In fact, the opposite is true. You have to continually invent new structures and materials to allow feature-size scaling, which is critical for active power reduction and for cost. SMD: But wires don’t scale well. How do you deal with that? Bohr: RC delay gets worse as you scale, compared with transistors, which tend to get faster as you scale down. The industry has had 20-plus years of struggling with that problem. One way we’ve addressed that is that we’re no longer striving for very high operating frequency, especially in the phone market where 2 or 2.5GHz would probably be sufficient. That’s one advantage. The other advantage is that the average size of the chips is smaller in these laptop and cell phone applications so you don’t have interconnects traveling a long distance across a large chip. Instead, it’s a more compact chip so the signals don’t have to go as far. But even with those chips, we still have a challenge of performance from the interconnect. We have to be clever about what pitches we choose. Some of the lower layers are dense pitch, where density is important. Some of the upper layers are coarser pitch, where performance is important. We’re also continuing to drive down interconnect capacitance by employing lower-k dielectrics. SMD: Is the interconnect becoming more problematic? Bohr: If you talk to a designer 10 years ago you would have heard the same thing. Maybe now they’re saying, ‘This time we’re really serious.’ SMD: How about new interconnect technology? Bohr: It’s hard to replace copper and low-k other than by making lower k. But at least in the low-power cell phone market, stacking chips does help to minimize some of the interconnect issues, particularly between the logic and the memory chips. SMD: You’re referring to through-silicon vias? Bohr: Yes. SMD: So if Intel is planning to get into that market, the company is experimenting with that technology right now? Bohr: Yes, and we’ve been public about exploring TSV and 3D technology for a couple years. Although there are some challenging technology aspects, the real issue is cost. Doing TSVs and stacking chips—especially these custom Wide I/O chips—is expensive. So this might be a better engineering solution in terms of density, performance and power, but will the market bear the added cost? Not all markets will bear the higher cost.

Message.Title: window 8 marketing campaign to top $1.4 Billion ............ WHOAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA
Message.Msg: t may seem like we’ve been hearing about Window 8 forever, but Microsoft’s marketing campaign for the new OS is just getting started. The software giant is set to spend an estimated $1.5 to $1.8 billion on the Windows 8 roll out, according to a blog by David Einstein in Forbes, who says that would make it the biggest launch in the history of the tech industry. Tech analyst Rob Enderle adds that Microsoft’s marketing push will be “on a scale you don’t see outside presidential elections.” Windows 8 for x86-based PCs and tablets, and its sister release, Windows RT for ARM-based tablets, are set to be released on October 26.

Message.Title: Capex to Sales ratio foundries vs Intel
Message.Msg: Monday, October 15th, 2012 By Mark LaPedus In total, silicon foundry capital spending is expected to reach about $21 billion in 2012, flat from 2011, according to Barclays Capital. In 2013, foundry CapEx is expected to fall 1% to 20.9 billion, according to the firm. TSMC will see its CapEx jump from $8 billion in 2012 to $9 billion in 2013, but Samsung LSI’s CapEx will fall from 8 trillion won in 2012 to 6 trillion won in 2013, according to the firm. “We model GlobalFoundries CapEx inching up slightly to $3.7 billion in 2013 from $3.4 billion in 2012, and UMC CapEx moving slightly higher to $2 billion in 2013 from $1.8 billion in 2012,” said C.J. Muse, an analyst with Barclays. Muse also predicts total CapEx will fall about 5% in 2012, compared to flat in the previous forecast. He lowered his overall CapEx outlook for 2013 to minus 10%, compared to flat to minus 5% in the previous forecast. Foundries, leading-edge nodes, and profits: Narrowing the field in a two-man race More Sharing ServicesShare Print Email Save By James Montgomery News Editor September 28, 2012 - Want another snapshot of who's leading the pack among pure-play foundries, and who's falling off the curve? Look more closely at 0.18μ) technologies will account for 13%, down from 14% in 2011 and 15% in 2010. GlobalFoundries, which earlier this year passed UMC to become the No.2 foundry, has rapidly narrowed the technology gap enjoyed by TSMC over its foundry rivals. GF actually has had a significantly higher percentage of its sales coming from 45nm and below process technologies than TSMC (55% vs. 26% in 2011, 65% vs. 37% in 2012), thanks to its MPU-centric focus. TSMC's still far ahead in terms of actual dollars ($3.8B vs. $1.9B in 2011, $6.2B vs. $2.8B in 2012). In contrast, look at the next two "Big 4" pureplay foundries: UMC's

Topic.Title: Intel is a ZOMBIE STOCK!

Message.Msg: YIKES!!! Pretty funny. He was talking about AMD. WEDNESDAY Anders said that Intel was a BUY. Why Intel Is a Buy Right Now By Anders Bylund Oct 17th FRIDAY Anders decribed AMD. I Give Up On This Zombie Stock! By Anders Bylund October 19, 2012 Advanced Micro Devices (NYSE: AMD ) just reported a disastrous third quarter. How bad was it? Let me count the ways: •Sales plunged 25% year over year, but we knew that already. •The year-ago period's $0.15 of non-GAAP earnings per share morphed into a loss of $0.20 per share. •AMD had to write off $100 million of chip inventory that nobody wanted to buy. AMD isn't fixing this by working harder to create great products. The company is running in the opposite direction by... •...firing 15% of its workforce in a cost-cutting panic. The new goal for operating expenses is to break even at quarterly revenue of roughly $1.3 billion, and it'll take about four quarters to get there. Just to rub salt in the fresh wound, rumor has it that AMD's guillotine will fall in exactly the wrong place, with most of the cuts coming from the engineering department -- the one place where AMD could save itself by investing more and getting better. Say it ain't so! I hope that rumor is totally false. Sadly, it seems like exactly the thing a purely financial dude like CEO Rory Read would do. Predecessor Dirk Meyer was an engineer himself, and would never have gotten AMD into this unholy mess. Look, bad things happen to good companies. But the great ones roll up their sleeves and fight back. AMD's cost-cutting instinct reminds me of a zombie's fixation on brains.

Keller will now serve as chief architect of AMD's (NYSE: AMD) chip designs, working on products spanning data centers, PCs and mobile devices.

Topic.Title: Intel at this price - Excellent Long term investment, sketchy short term investment

Message.Msg: Within 2-3 years, it is just as likely that the US will have another recession. There is no such thing as an excellent long term investment in a semiconductor stock. Both INTC and the SMH are well below the peaks they reached off the o3 bottom way back in 2004, the SMH was 45.00, INTC was 34.00. Both made lower lows in 2009 than in 2003, the SMH had gone to 15.00. INTC at 12.00, a mere 66 percent off the highs for the SMH, falling far more than the nasdaq. When, not if, another recession hits, they will once again, as recently, dramatically underform the market. All in all chips are just a commodity, useless without demand for the product they go into as evidenced by AMD's need to write down the cost of useless chips headed to the chip graveyard.

Message.Title: Im a PC. Heres why
Message.Msg: I bought a tablet a couple days ago. Its going back. All it really is is a bigger version of my phone. You cannot do what Im doing right now on a tablet. Listen to and download music, play a game and type here at the same time. No ports for my speakers or guitar port, minimal storage, cant burn anything. Google tablets arent even flash based which suck for stock charts. Not a mac guy, never will be. Maybe Ipad is different. Long INTC at 25 selling calls all the way down. If MSFT releases a tablet that responds like a laptop with all the goodies watch out. Intel inside

Topic.Title: Intel at this price - Excellent Long term investment, sketchy short term investment

Message.Msg: The facts are the facts, in 2004, INTC peaked at 34, the SMH at 45.00, AMAT at 26.00. Those were the peaks after the bubble of a bunch of fools thinking the computer age was new (it was in 1985 and before) collapsed in on itself starting in March of 2000 with the semiconductor stocks getting the brunt of the collapse, by March 2003 the markets bottomed and INTC and the SMH rallied to their recovery peaks in 2004, price levels not seen since those peaks and well above where they are now. By 2009, the SMH had INTC had fallen well below the March 2003 lows. As even any die hard long has to know, during this minor overall market correction, the SMH now sits well below it's May high which was above the overbght high hit when INTC last hit close to 27.50, the semis have dramatically underperformed the market. As sure as night follows day, there will be another recession, and when it comes, the semis will do what they have been doing for years, dramatically underperform the market. Brag all you want about have a 5 figure number of INTC shares from under 21.00. It's a mere .29 above that level, a net cost of sitting on ones hands of 8.00 times the number of shares owned. and anyone who has been holding INTC for 20 years should be horsewhipped or worse, for not selling at the peak of the idiotic bubble of 2000 when INTC was 80 and the SMH 100.00. I am not saying INTC is a sell at current levels, I am saying there is no such thing as a good long term investment in any semiconductor stock, and there will most assuredly at some point likely in the near future, be another recession. In the near future, if the markets head back up, I'll go long again, likely the QLD. When they go down, the SQQQ.
